title: Exploratory_Functions

what: Show a data frame in MS Excel
title: Exploratory_Functions
text: can also used pipes.
code: show_in_excel(df) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union df %>%     show_in_excel()

title: Exploratory_Functions
text: ’m initialising vector 1 10 fifth value missing NA. Using which_na(), can find index element vector NA.

title: Exploratory_Functions
text: can identify values satisfy criteria. kind wrapper around dplyr’s filter().
code: which_this(iris, "Sepal.Length > 7") #>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width   Species #> 1           7.1         3.0          5.9         2.1 virginica #> 2           7.6         3.0          6.6         2.1 virginica #> 3           7.3         2.9          6.3         1.8 virginica #> 4           7.2         3.6          6.1         2.5 virginica #> 5           7.7         3.8          6.7         2.2 virginica #> 6           7.7         2.6          6.9         2.3 virginica #> 7           7.7         2.8          6.7         2.0 virginica #> 8           7.2         3.2          6.0         1.8 virginica #> 9           7.2         3.0          5.8         1.6 virginica #> 10          7.4         2.8          6.1         1.9 virginica #> 11          7.9         3.8          6.4         2.0 virginica #> 12          7.7         3.0          6.1         2.3 virginica

title: GG-Serif_Theme
code: iris %>%    ggplot(aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() +   labs(title = "Without my theme")

title: GG-Serif_Theme
code: iris %>%     ggplot(aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +    geom_point() +    labs(title = "With my theme") +    ggserif()

title: GG-Serif_Theme
text: can set theme globally plots using following command.

what: Removing Rows Based on Missing Values in a Column
title: Manipulative_Functions
text: Sometimes, want na.omit() treat features equally. want check values one column, removing observations.
code: # First ten rows of iris dataset df = iris[1:10,] df #>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1           5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2           4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3           4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4           4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5           5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6           5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa #> 7           4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3  setosa #> 8           5.0         3.4          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 9           4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1  setosa  # Setting second sepal width to NA df$Sepal.Width[2] = NA df #>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1           5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2           4.9          NA          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3           4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4           4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5           5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6           5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa #> 7           4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3  setosa #> 8           5.0         3.4          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 9           4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1  setosa  # Removing that observation df = na_rm_feature(df, "Sepal.Width") df #>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1           5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3           4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4           4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5           5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6           5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa #> 7           4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3  setosa #> 8           5.0         3.4          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 9           4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1  setosa

title: Manipulative_Functions

code: # First ten rows of iris dataset df = iris[1:10,] df #>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1           5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2           4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3           4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4           4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5           5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6           5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa #> 7           4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3  setosa #> 8           5.0         3.4          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 9           4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1  setosa  # Setting second sepal width to NA df$Sepal.Width[2] = NA df #>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1           5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2           4.9          NA          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3           4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4           4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5           5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6           5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa #> 7           4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3  setosa #> 8           5.0         3.4          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 9           4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1  setosa na_to_zero(df$Sepal.Width) #>  [1] 3.5 0.0 3.2 3.1 3.6 3.9 3.4 3.4 2.9 3.1

what: Some R Functions I Use Rather Frequently
title: Some R Functions I Use Rather Frequently
text: functions use frequently projects. three categories functions: exploratory functions check missing values describe data, visualisation functions ggplot2 themes manipulative functions modify selected variables. See vignettes details.

text: NULL function return value.

title: Personal `ggplot2` theme with serif fonts and directed axes — ggserif
code: # Set theme globally by ggplot2::theme_set(ggserif())  # Or use it for a single plot ggplot2::ggplot(iris, ggplot2::aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) + ggplot2::geom_point() + ggplot2::theme_set(ggserif())
